newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: EU gives Iraq oil for food deal qualified approval.
newsitem.headline: EU gives Iraq oil for food deal qualified approval.

text.p: European Union states want the Iraqi food-for-oil deal to go ahead when the United Nations Secretary General approves it, Irish Foreign Minister Dick Spring said on Saturday.
"We want to see that (the deal) as soon as conditions are right on the ground," Spring told reporters during a break in informal talks among EU foreign ministers in Tralee, southern Ireland.
Spring said the EU was split over reaction to U.S. attacks against Iraq but wanted the deal, which will allow Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil in return for food and medical supplies, to go ahead.
He said it was up to United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to decide when that should be.
EU member France has voiced reservations about the U.S. attack on Iraq ordered to punish Saddam Hussein's invasion of parts of Kurdish areas in northern Iraq.
Irish officials said that France appeared isolated in its opposition but said an EU statement would back Paris's line that the territorial integrity of all states in the region had to be respected.
An EU statement would condemn Iraq's attack because it upset regional stability and call on Baghdad to withdraw its forces from the Kurdish region, the officials said.
The statement was expected to be issued at the end of the informal talks some time on Sunday.
